oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Effect of Rubber Flooring on the Development of Claw Lesions in Lactating Dairy Cows Housed in Free Stall Barns
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Vanegas, J.
Overton, M. W.
Sischo, W. M.
Berry, S. L.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: confinement production systems
lameness
ousing factors
concrete flooring
claw lesions
rubber flooring
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: With the increased numbers of confinement dairy production systems, lameness has become a major economic cost to the dairy industry. Housing factors, specifically related to concrete flooring in free stall barns, have been associated with an increased risk of claw lesions and clinical lameness. Research has suggested that alternative flooring surfaces may prevent or decrease the occurrence of lameness and claw lesions. The objective of this study was to determine the effect of rubber flooring on the occurrence of claw lesions, clinical lameness and hoof growth and wear.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: American Association of Bovine Practitioners Conference Proceedings; 2005; 188
